Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Smart Mobility Services: Operations and Policy

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to develop methods for the modeling and optimization of smart mobility services. Bike sharing programs, smart parking systems, and person-2-person car sharing are the focus of the research program. The research will contribute to the analysis of spatial nonstationary queueing networks. The research program includes empirical analysis, analytic modeling, and simulation studies of the aforementioned smart mobility services. The tangible products of this research includes software and algorithms for the management of these smart mobility services, documentation of research results, evaluation of pilot programs, issues of an operations research graphic novel, and the development of educational materials on smart mobility services.
The results of this research will encourage the further development and deployment of smart mobility services. These services are accessible and energy efficient transportation modes. Accessibility to transportation is a key employment, economic, and help indicator, particularly in low income and minority communities. The wide adoption of smart mobility services contributes to the U.S. policy goal of dramatically reducing the amount of greenhouse gases that are generated by the transportation sector. The investigator has partnerships with several organizations to apply the research findings directly to the development of bike sharing in Paris, smart parking in Pittsburgh, PA, and person-2-person car sharing in Chicago. Furthermore, the research and education plan supports the increased participation of African Americans in the mathematical sciences through involvement in the Conference for African American Researchers in the Mathematical Sciences (CAARMS). Additionally, the investigator writes a graphic novel that introduces public audiences to operations research. The award supports an expansion of this effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this grant were to develop new analytic methods and approximations for the optimization of smart mobility services: bike sharing programs, smart parking systems,and person-2-person carsharing.

 Over the course of this grant, we published among the first research on bike sharing capacity planning redistribution and travel behavior. This work developed optimization models to increase the availability of bikes by efficiently redistributing bikes throughout the system. We tested our methods on many systems around the world test including Paris, Washington D.C., Boston, Barcelona and Seville. 

Our smart parking work has shown, via a large scale field experiement in Sanf Francisco, that dynamic parking meter pricing can lead to reduced road congestion and pollution. This result has  significant impact on society. As our cities become more crowded and congested, the environomental impacts of driving are dramtically increasing. Given that all vehicle trips end with a parked car, our results identify an evidenced based intervention that reduces congestion and pollution. 

Our results on smart parking has been both policy and academically relevant. This work has received the Intelligent transportation Society of America Spotlight award in 2011. Our smart parking work San Francisco has been replicated in many other cities around the world. The resulting publications have appeared in leading transportation journals (TRA,TRR) as well as a leading urban planning journal (JAPA) and the leading practice-oriented operations research journal (InterfaceS).This work included methodological approaches from econometrics, queueing theory, revenue management and machine learning.

Additionally, we published the first papers on peer-2-peer carsharing capacity planning , simulation and design. 

This grant has supported 2 completed PhD dissertations and a Post-doctoral fellw. As well as over, 10 masters students, and 5 undergradutes (via REU supplements.) This award has had direct impact on increasing the number of underpresented researchers. One African American male PhD student and a post-doc was supported by this grant. Additionally, two undergraduate African American male student participated in the research and were authors on a peer-reviewed publication. The PI presented the results and findings of this project 3 times at the Conference for African American Researchers in the Mathematical Sciences (CAARMS). Finally, an African-American female research assistant supported by this project went on to become a city council member in the City of San Franciso. As a city council member she has taken her research experience on this project to directly develop policies to increase access to  bike sharing and car sharing services.
